Ombudsman: Nadiem Juga Harus Pikirkan Sekolah Daerah Terpencil
01 Nov 2019, 03:31 by Antara, Yudono Yanuar
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Anggota Ombudsman Republik Indonesia (ORI) Ahmad Suadi meminta Menteri Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan Nadiem Makarim tidak hanya peduli dengan digitalisasi sekolah, namun juga pembangunan gedung sekolah yang masih kurang, terutama di daerah terpencil.
"Jadi bukan hanya pendidikan digital saja, fasilitas dan prasarana sekolah juga jangan dilupakan," katanya dalam keterangan tertulis di Jakarta, Kamis, 31 Oktober 2019.
Ia menjelaskan selama ini masih banyak daerah yang belum memiliki sekolah dan ada juga sekolah yang mengalami kerusakan.
Selain itu, Ombudsman banyak menampung keluhan dari masyarakat soal kebijakan penerimaan siswa baru dengan sistem zonasi.
"Setiap tahun selalu masuk keluhan masyarakat mengenai sistem zonasi. Selain itu juga banyak keluhan terkait kebijakan pemerintah daerah untuk melakukan ujian nasional menggunakan komputer, pada siswa yang sekolahnya belum punya fasilitas komputer atau di daerah terpencil yang belum ada jaringan internet," katanya.
Akibatnya, siswa dari daerah terpencil harus menumpang ke sekolah lain untuk melaksanakan ujian nasional.
Ahli ekonomi Prof Dr Emil Salim mengatakan pendapatan negara, terutama pendapatan negara yang surplus, harus digunakan untuk pembangunan infrastruktur yang dirasakan langsung oleh banyak masyarakat.
"Bukan hanya asal bangun infrastruktur saja," katanya.
Emil Salim memberi contoh bagaimana pemerintah Indonesia menggunakan surplus dari kenaikan neraca minyak bumi yang terjadi pada tahun 70-an untuk pembangunan sekolah-sekolah di desa dan daerah tertinggal.
Menurut dia, Presiden Soeharto pada waktu itu langsung terjun ke lapangan dan Presiden Soeharto mengatakan harus membangun sekolah-sekolah itu supaya terjadi pemerataan pada masyarakat, terutama pemerataan pendidikan sekolah dasar di Indonesia.
"Masyarakat tahu mereka harus sekolah tetapi pada waktu itu belum ada gedung sekolah. Saat gedung-gedung sekolah selesai dibangun, dinamika semangat untuk sekolah tinggi dan tercapailah pemerataan," katanya.
Keberhasilan SD Inpres itu bahkan mengantarkan salah satu dari tiga ekonom asal Amerika meraih Nobel. Mereka adalah Abhijit Banerjee, Esther Duflo dan Michael Kremer.
Penelitian Duflo diterbitkan di Agustus tahun 2000 dengan judul "schooling and labor market consequences of school construction in Indonesia: evidence from an unusual policy experiment" atau konsekuensi sekolah dan pasar tenaga kerja dari pembangunan sekolah di Indonesia: bukti dari eksperimen kebijakan yang tidak biasa.
Dalam abstraksinya ia menjelaskan penelitian ini berbasis pada realita yang terjadi di Indonesia tahun 1973 dan 1978, yang mana Indonesia membangun lebih dari 61.000 SD. Dalam risetnya, itu menunjukkan bahwa pembangunan SD Inpres menyebabkan peningkatan pendidikan dan pendapatan di Indonesia.

Ombudsman: Nadiem Must Also Think of Remote Regional Schools
Nov 01 2019, 03:31 by Antara, Yudono Yanuar
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Indonesian Ombudsman (ORI) member Ahmad Suadi asked Minister of Education and Culture Nadiem Makarim not only to care about digitizing schools, but also the construction of school buildings that were still lacking, especially in remote areas.
"So it is not just digital education, school facilities and infrastructure must not be forgotten," he said in a written statement in Jakarta, Thursday, 31 October 2019.
He explained that so far there were still many areas that did not have schools and there were also schools that were damaged.
In addition, the Ombudsman accommodates complaints from the public about the policy of accepting new students with the zoning system.
"Every year there are always complaints from the public about the zoning system. In addition, there are also many complaints related to the local government's policy to conduct a national exam using computers, to students whose schools do not have computer facilities or in remote areas where there is no internet network," he said.
As a result, students from remote areas have to hitchhike to other schools to carry out national examinations.
Economist Prof. Dr. Emil Salim said state revenues, especially surplus state revenues, must be used for infrastructure development that is felt directly by many people.
"It's not just the origin of infrastructure," he said.
Emil Salim gave an example of how the Indonesian government used the surplus from the increase in the petroleum balance that occurred in the 70s for the construction of schools in villages and underdeveloped areas.
According to him, President Soeharto at that time went straight into the field and President Soeharto said that he had to build schools so that there could be equity in the community, especially in the distribution of primary school education in Indonesia.
"The community knew they had to go to school but at that time there were no school buildings. When the school buildings were completed, the dynamics of enthusiasm for high schools and equality were achieved," he said.
The success of SD Inpres even led one of the three American economists to win the Nobel Prize. They are Abhijit Banerjee, Esther Duflo and Michael Kremer.
Duflo's research was published in August 2000 under the title "Schooling and labor market Consequences of school construction in Indonesia: evidence from an unusual policy experiment" or the consequences of schools and the labor market from school construction in Indonesia: evidence of unusual policy experiments.
In his abstract, he explained that this research was based on the reality that occurred in Indonesia in 1973 and 1978, in which Indonesia built more than 61,000 elementary schools. In his research, it shows that the construction of SD Inpres has led to an increase in education and income in Indonesia.
